School of Energy Science and Engineering, University of Science and Technology of China Hefei 230026 China 1 These authors contribute equally to this work Cyclopentanone (CPO) is a versatile chemical intermediate with great industrial relevance. In this work, a sustainable one-pot process converting xylose to CPO was developed via biphasic solvent engineering and a multifunctional Co/Nb2O5 catalyst, overcoming challenges of intermediate condensation and catalyst poisoning. Biphasic solvent system was formulated to integrate the two-stage process, based on the partitioning behavior of key intermediates to avoid unfavorable condensation while maintaining effective acid-assisted ring arrangement in aqueous phase. Co/Nb2O5 outperformed noble metals with 53 % CPO selectivity, attributed to its dual Brönsted/Lewis acidity, moderate hydrogenation capability, and resistance to carboxylic acid byproducts poisoning. Further structure-activity relationship analysis demonstrated that reduction temperature dependent Coδ+ species are critical for FFR conversion, with Coδ+/Cototal ratio presented a linear correlation with FFR conversion rate. This integrated strategy eliminates energy-intensive steps, offering a practical guidance toward catalytic reaction system design for facile and efficient one-pot conversion of xylose to industrially high-value compounds. Graphical Abstract Keywords Xylose-to-cyclopentanone One-pot process Biphasic system Co/Nb2O5 catalyst Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the context of diminishing fossil resources and escalating environmental concerns, the development of green and economical production methods for high-value fuels and chemicals has become increasingly urgent. Cyclopentanone (CPO) is a versatile chemical intermediate plays a critical role in the synthesis of sustainable aviation fuels, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and advanced materials [1], which currently relies on petrochemical routes plagued by high energy consumption and pollution [2]. Lignocellulose-derived platform chemicals, particularly C5 sugars derived from hemicellulose, offers a renewable alternative for CPO synthesis [3]. This approach aligns with global demands for carbon-neutral chemical production and circular bioeconomy frameworks. In 2012, Hronec et al. developed a pioneering reductive conversion route using furfural (FFR) as the starting material in aqueous phase, achieving a high yield of 76.5 % biogenic CPO with a Pt/C catalyst [4]. This conversion process involves multiple sequential reactions including hydrogenation, ring arrangement and hydrodeoxygenation, requiring synergistic effect of multiple active sites. Since that, numerous studies have been conducted to facilitate this sustainable approach as a green alternative for CPO production [5]. In most current studies, FFR is used as the starting material that is produced from an acid-catalyzed conversion of saccharides (i.e., hemicellulose, xylan, and xylose). Extra processing time, intense labor input and high energy consumption for the FFR separation step limits the upstream-downstream mode, leaving room for further development in a more efficient and economical manner. Therefore, synthesis of CPO from xylose directly via one-pot conversion to bypass FFR separation is highly desirable because of higher atom economy, faster production rate and greater energy efficiency thereof. Solid acid catalysts with balanced acidic functionalities are pivotal for one-pot xylose conversion, where Brønsted acid sites drive xylose dehydration and furan ring rearrangement, while Lewis acid sites enable isomerization and hydrodeoxygenation. Nb2O5 exemplifies this dual-acid synergy, leveraging hydrated sites for Brønsted acidity and open metal sites for Lewis acidity, facilitating sequential xylose-to-FFR transformation and subsequent reductive upgrading [6]. Metal-supported Nb₂O₅ catalysts as a water-stable material are widely applied in reductive conversion of furanic compounds under aqueous condition [7,8], achieving 92 % CPO yield through enhanced metal-support interactions [9]. However, catalyst poisoning and coking critically degrade catalytic performance in xylose conversion, primarily driven by strongly chemisorbed by-products (e.g., carboxylic acids) or impurities [10]. In aqueous xylose conversion, small carboxylic acids like formic acid generate carbon monoxide via acid-mediated dehydration, irreversibly poisoning precious metal catalysts in downstream hydrogenation [11–13]. This underscores the necessity of designing Nb2O5-based systems with intrinsic poisoning resistance, where the synergistic stabilization of active sites and selective intermediate adsorption mitigate deactivation, enabling seamless integration of dehydration and hydrogenation steps within a one-pot conversion. The solvent system critically governs CPO production efficiency by modulating humin formation via condensation of reactive intermediates like FFR and FOL [14,15]. While aqueous systems suffer from significant mass loss, biphasic systems (e.g., water/organic phases with MIBK, toluene, or 2-methyltetrahydrofuran) mitigate this by in situ extraction of intermediates [16–18]. On the other hand, the interaction of reactant and product could direct reaction pathways, where Nijhuis et al. found that the increase of organic solvent hydrophobicity in a biphasic system suppress xylose hydrogenation to xylitol, favoring FFR-based routes [19]. However, existing studies predominantly focus on final product stabilization in the organic phase [20–22], neglecting intermediate partitioning dynamics, which directly regulate reaction pathways and product selectivity. A paradigm shift toward analyzing phase affinity of key intermediates could refine solvent design to steer pathways (e.g., enhancing CPO selectivity) while minimizing deactivation or side reactions. This work presents a one-pot strategy using M/Nb2O5 catalyst in tandem with tailored biphasic solvents, achieving high CPO yields directly from xylose. Biphasic solvent systems were formulated based on the partitioning behavior of key intermediates to avoid unfavorable condensation while maintaining effective acid-assisted ring arrangement in aqueous phase. By coupling non-precious metal catalysis with solvent-driven pathway control, this approach offers a scalable, economically viable route for bio-based CPO production, with potential applications in sustainable aviation fuel synthesis and high-value chemical manufacturing. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Partitioning behavior of key intermediates in biphasic solvent systems To develop a one-pot sequential dehydration-reductive conversion process, a biphasic solvent system that is compatible with both stages is crucial. Specifically, the distribution of key intermediates (such as FFR, furfuryl alcohol (FOL), 2-cyclopentenone (CPEO)) and (by-)products (CPO, cyclopentanol (CPOL)) involved in the conversion process significantly impacts the reaction pathway and product selectivity [23,24]. As illustrated in Fig. 1a, while the aqueous phase hosts the catalyst and facilitates hydrogenation, ring rearrangement, and hydrodeoxygenation, uncontrolled condensation of intermediates in this phase remains a dominant side reaction. To systematically evaluate partitioning dynamics, we calculated the partition coefficients (Kp) of these compounds in various biphasic systems, where Kp (or 1/Kp) quantifies their preference for the organic or aqueous phase (Fig. 1b, Table S1). For non-polar or less polar organic solvents (cyclohexane, dodecane, and n-hexane), low Kp values indicate strong aqueous-phase retention of intermediates (Fig. 1b). Particularly, the Kp of FOL in the three biphasic solvent systems are in the range of 0.03–0.06, implying that FOL would be instantaneously concentrated in aqueous phase upon formation from FFR. This might cause unfavorable condensation, oligomerization and coking on the surface of acid catalyst [25], as evidenced by TGA analysis showing a 5 % greater weight loss for catalysts recovered from dodecane/water compared to toluene/water (Figure S1). Conversely, high polarity solvents like MIBK or n-butanol exhibit high Kp values for all tests compounds, extracting intermediates into the organic phase. Unlike the scenarios in the above, toluene/water solvent system showed a divergent Kp distribution, where FFR and CPO have high Kp value (high organic phase affinity), and other three compounds (FOL, CPEO, and CPOL) show a slightly higher water affinity. 2.2 Impact of biphasic solvent systems on xylose dehydration to FFR The relationship between partition coefficients and xylose-to-FFR yield was experimentally validated using Nb2O5 as a solid acid catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 2a, biphasic systems with higher Kp values typically showed enhanced FFR yields. For instance, MIBK/water and toluene/water and achieved a respective 60.1 % and 84.3 % FFR yield by rapid extraction into the organic phase, thereby minimizing aqueous-phase condensation. Previous studies also indicated an approximately positive correlation between partition coefficient and FFR selectivity from xylose dehydration [26]. In contrast, non-polar organic phase like cyclohexane, hexane and dodecane/water (Kp < 0.6) retained intermediates in the aqueous phase, leading to reduced yields of FFR (∼40 %-50 %). Notably, butanol/water (Kp = 4.11) system showed an unexpectedly low yield under this reaction condition, which might be attributed to the interference of acid-catalyzed protonation due to competitive hydrogen bonding of butanol [26,27]. Overall, these biphasic solvent systems can be ordered as toluene/H2O (84.28 %) > MIBK/H2O (60.45 %) > n-hexane/H2O (53.74 %) ≈ cyclohexane/H2O (49.93 %) > dodecane/H2O (40.62 %) ≈ butanol/H2O (39.07 %) according to the FFR yield. As a comparison, the FFR yield in water monophasic solvent (14.0 %) is significantly lower than that in biphasic system, illustrating the effectiveness of biphasic system for FFR formation. Using the optimal toluene/water system, subsequent studies explored variations in solid acid materials and reaction parameters (Figure S2). Optimal conditions (180°C, 2 MPa N2, 6 h) were identified and later applied to cascade one-pot processes. These findings emphasize that solvent formulation in biphasic catalysis should balance both partitioning behavior and chemical compatibility with the catalyst. 2.3 Solvent-driven pathway modulation for FFR hydrogenation to CPO To extend the biphasic solvent analysis, we further evaluated FFR hydrogenation performance in select solvent systems using Pd/Nb2O5 as a bifunctional catalyst. It can be seen in Fig. 2b that systems with excessive organic-phase retention (MIBK/water and butanol/water) led to incomplete conversion. Notably, FOL’s preferential partitioning into MIBK and butanol cause spatial segregation that disrupts proton transfer required for Piancatelli rearrangement [28], stalling the reaction at FOL and suppressing CPO formation. The effect was most pronounced in butanol/water, where FOL retention led to negligible CPO yield (<10 %). In contrast, the balanced partitioning of intermediates in toluene/water allows partial aqueous retention of FOL and CPEO for sequential reactions while extracting FFR/CPO to suppress side reactions. This equilibrium enabled sequential hydrogenation and acid-catalyzed steps to achieve the highest CPO yield (60 %), highlighting the need for phase-specific accessibility of intermediates during one-pot cascade transformations [29]. Regardless of solvent system, the strong hydrogenation activity of Pd facilitates over-reduction to THFOL, associated with ring saturation by strong hydrogenation capacity of Pd, necessitating a re-evaluation on the catalyst for CPO production through one-pot xylose conversion. 2.4 M/Nb2O5 catalysts screening for one-pot xylose conversion The selection and design of catalysts are crucial for the reaction activity. To optimize the cascade conversion of xylose to CPO in the toluene/water biphasic system, we screened a series of Nb2O5-supported redox-active metal catalysts, including precious metals (Ru, Pd, Pt) and non-precious analogs (Cu, Ni, Mo, Mn, Co) [30–32]. Initial evaluation focused on their ability to drive the hydrogenation-rearrangement cascade from FFR to CPO ( Fig. 3). Among the tested catalysts, Co/Nb2O5 emerged as the best candidate achieving 70.0 % CPO yield, surpassing noble metal analogs like Pt/Nb2O5 (63.5 %) and Pd/Nb2O5 (59.6 %). This underscores Co’s unique capacity to balance selective hydrogenation and suppression of over-hydrogenation (versus intense furan ring saturation of Pd, Ru and Ni) [33]. Low FFR conversion and no CPO was detected using Mn, Mo and Cu catalysts, even though these metals are conventionally used in HDO-related work [34,35]. When transitioning to one-pot conversion developed using xylose as the starting substrate, however, CPO yields plummeted for all precious metal catalysts, with Ru, Pd, and Pt showed ≤ 15 % CPO selectivity. Only FFR (no CPO) product was found in Mn, Mo, Cu-based catalyst, indicating stalled catalysis after xylose dehydration. In contrast, Co retained 43 % CPO yield, closely matching the theoretical maximum (product of 80 % xylose-to-FFR and 60 % FFR-to-CPO efficiencies). This contrasts sharply with platinum-group metals (PGMs), which typically excel in hydrogenation/HDO but failed here. 2.5 Uncovering catalyst poisoning mechanisms To understand possible mechanism attributes to the disparity of CPO yield between precious metals and Co based catalyst, we thoroughly analyzed product stream from the first dehydration step via GC-MS following silyation (Figure S3). Besides the dominant FFR peak, there are multiple other by-product signals present in the stream, among which formic acid and lactic acid were detected as two major by-products, consistent with precedent studies on xylose dehydration [36]. Under the reaction condition for the second stage, it has been reported that these small carboxylic acids are prone to decomposition to form CO and H2O through dehydration pathway on PGM surface [37], and thus causes catalyst poisoning due to irreversible adsorption of CO on the active metal sites [38,39]. A validation test was conducted by adding marginal formic acid and lactic acid into FFR-to-CPO reductive conversion step. As shown in Fig. 4, significant decrease in FFR conversion and CPO yield was witnessed when using Ru/Nb2O5, Pd/Nb2O5 and Pt/Nb2O5, compared with the reaction condition without the two carboxylic acids addition. In contrast, its impact on CPO yield for Co/Nb2O5 was almost negligible, demonstrating an outstanding anti-poisoning property of this cobalt based catalyst. Cobalt’s resilience stems from its moderate hydrogen dissociation capacity, which suppresses CO generation from acidic by-products. Unlike PGMs, the retarded hydrogen dissociation capacity of cobalt minimizes decarbonylation pathways, avoiding CO formation and subsequent poisoning [40,41]. This property also aligns with its selective hydrogenation behavior, which balances FFR reduction (to enable CPO formation) while resisting over-hydrogenation (e.g., furan saturation to THFOL). 2.6 Process optimization for Co/Nb2O5 catalyzed one-pot xylose conversion Reaction temperature and pressure were first optimized for Co/Nb2O5 catalyzed xylose conversion (Figures S4 and S5). At low reaction temperatures, FOL accumulates considerably due to low efficiency in initiating the acid-driven ring rearrangement [42], while CPO selectivity and carbon balance dropped sharply at elevated reaction temperatures. Over-hydrogenation of furan ring occurred and THFOL by-product was generated as the hydrogen pressure goes too high. Further optimization comparing various toluene/water ratios showed that higher water proportion accelerate CPOL formation, while higher toluene proportion resulted in slower conversion FFR and FOL. The 1:1 ratio provided optimal extraction efficiency and catalytic activity (Figure S6). Overall, 4 MPa and 160 °C in toluene/water (1:1) is selected for the hydrogenation step during the one-pot conversion process. The effect of Co loading is also investigated (Figure S7). The CPO yield increases rapidly from 1 % to 10 % metal loading, and the yield of CPO reached the maximum of 43 % at 10 % Co loading. Further increase of Co loading to 20 % results in over-hydrogenation product CPOL. Obviously, cobalt based catalysts are less robust in hydro-conversion process compared with other precious metals, and thus requires higher metal loading for the hydrogenation process in this study [42,43]. However, the dual consequences derived from the retarded hydrogenation capacity of cobalt also result in the incapability of CO formation and immunity of carboxylic acid poisoning. 2.7 Characterization of Co/Nb2O5 catalysts tuned by varied reduction temperatures In order to further understand the Co/Nb2O5 catalyst structure - CPO selectivity relationship through the one-pot xylose conversion, we further tuned the reduction temperature of Co/Nb2O5 catalysts following identical calcination protocol. The scanning electron microscope (SEM) image of Co/Nb2O5 reveals a irregular particle morphology with rough surfaces (Figure S8), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of Co/Nb2O5 catalysts showed that metal nanoparticles are homogeneously scattered throughout the support matrix ( Fig. 5). High-resolution TEM images displayed clear lattice fringes with the interplanar spacings of approximately 0.20 nm, which is indexed to (002) planes of Co0 [44]. Moreover, lattice fringes with a spacing of 0.39 nm is found in Co/Nb2O5-H(800) sample, which can be attributed to the higher crystalline degree of Nb2O5 support when treated under high temperature [45]. Elemental mapping images of Co/Nb2O5-H(550) further demonstrate that Co, O, and Nb were homogeneously distributed throughout the catalyst surface. XRD spectra showed no distinct characteristic peaks assigned to the highly dispersed Co species ( Fig. 6a). Instead, all catalysts share multiple sharp diffraction peaks of different planes of Nb2O5 (PDF#72–1484) or Nb16.8O42 (PDF#71–0336) [46]. Pyridine-FTIR was applied to evaluate acidic site type and their density on catalyst surface (Fig. 6b). All catalysts showed two dominant Lewis acid-bound pyridine peaks at 1450 and 1620 cm−1 [47]. The quantitative results in Table S2 demonstrated that the intensity of Lewis acid site in Co/Nb2O5-H(250) and -H(550) are similar, but - H(800) showed a sharp decrease which might be associated with the decrease of positively-charged Co species. Another two weak peaks appeared at 1488 and 1540 cm−1 were attributed to the adsorption of pyridine on Brönsted acid sites [48], decreasing gradually along with increasing reduction temperature. H2-TPR was used to analyze the reducible cobalt species in the catalyst activated under varied temperatures (Fig. 6c). H2-TPR trace of unreduced Co/Nb2O5 shows a prominent shoulder at 320 °C (β-peak) followed by a major H2 uptake peak centered at 350 °C (γ-peak), which are attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co⁰, respectively [49]. For Co/Nb2O5 catalysts reduced at 550 °C and 800 °C, no signals present at β- or γ-peak position, indicating these catalysts are fully reduced to metallic form at corresponding activation temperatures. Instead, a distinct reduction peak was shown at a lower temperature of 250 °C (α-peak), which is probably attributed to the presence of reactive interfacial Coδ+ (0 < δ ≤ 2) species that are prone to reduction at a lower temperature [50,51]. It has been demonstrated in multiple other studies that after reduction and in situ passivation (or air exposure), interfacial CoOx layer rich in electron-deficient Coδ+ species would come into formation [29,52]. For Co/Nb2O5-H(250) catalyst, the H2-TPR trace covers a broad temperature range that can be deconvoluted into three peaks, and the copresence of these peaks is due to insufficient reduction of oxide precursors at such temperature. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was further conducted to determine the oxidation state of Co/Nb2O5 catalysts based on the preliminary qualitive analysis above. As shown in Fig. 6d, the binding energy at 780.0 eV, 781.1 eV and 782.3 eV are the characteristic 2p3/2 peak of Co0, Co3+ and Coδ+ species, respectively [53,54]. The proportion of reactive Coδ+ species rose with reduction temperature and reached its peak at a reduction temperature of 550 °C (Table S3). Such partially reduced Coδ+ species could act as Lewis acid sites or electrophilic sites due to the unsaturated coordination state [55], which accounts for the abundant acidity in Co/Nb2O5-H(550). As the reduction temperature further increased to 800 °C, the peak intensity of metallic Co became dominant and the proportion of Coδ+ species dropped considerably. Such trend agrees with Das and Yadav’s work showing that mild reduction condition with intermediate metal support interaction favored the generation of partially reduced Coδ+ sites [56]. 2.8 Structure-activity relationship analysis of tailored Co/Nb2O5 catalysts The Co/Nb2O5 series catalysts were tested in the process of FFR-to-CPO conversion, and substrate conversion is high (∼90 %) for catalysts reduced at temperature lower than 550 °C ( Fig. 7a). As the reduction temperature continuously increases, the FFR conversion noticeably dropped to 85 % (Co/Nb2O5-H(650)) and 74.6 % (Co/Nb2O5-H(800)). Notably, unconverted intermediate FOL was observed in all cases, indicating furan ring arrangement is a rate-limiting step in this process. The FOL content decreases with reduction temperature till 550 °C, followed by a declination as temperature increases. As a result, a volcanic trend of CPO selectivity for the six Co/Nb2O5 catalysts was seen, with the catalytic performance peaked at Co/Nb2O5- H(550) (70 %) (Fig. 7a). Notably, physically mixing extra amount of Nb2O5 with Co/Nb2O5 or increasing Nb2O5 proportion in the Co/Nb2O5 catalyst could accelerate the conversion of FOL (Figure S9), validating that acid-mediated FOL rearrangement is a rate-limiting step. The catalyst exhibited good recyclability over three cycles with only a slight decline in CPO yield (Figure S10), and the XRD patterns of the catalysts showed no significant changes (Figure S11), further confirming the stability of the catalyst. The catalytic performance could be largely recovered after a simple regeneration treatment. As we moved on to apply xylose as the substrate, the hydrogenation performance follows a similar volcanic curve, with the catalyst reduced at 550 °C presented the highest CPO yield of 52.83 % (Fig. 7b). Time course study presented the changes of intermediates and product selectivity versus reaction time (Fig. 7c-e). Apparent reaction rate constants for FFR conversion of varied Co/Nb2O5 catalysts were calculated using the pseudo-first-order model (Figure S12), assuming that hydrogen is in significant excess [57]. The calculated reaction rate constant of FFR conversion decrease in the following order, Co/Nb2O5-H(550) (1.237 h−1) > Co/Nb2O5-H(250) (1.002 h−1) > Co/Nb2O5-H(800) (0.496 h−1). This trend is jointly attributed to metallic and Coδ+ species that exhibit synergistic effect in the multistep conversion process. Kim and coworkers found that FFR and FOL can be strongly adsorbed on the Coδ+ center, and the proximity between the Ni0 and Coδ+ sites favored the dissociative adsorption of H2 and subsequent hydrogen spillover to Coδ+, thereby greatly improve selectivity toward 1,5-pentanediol [58]. The results in our work could similarly be explained that a more balanced Co0 and Coδ+ sites in Co/Nb2O5-H(550) could facilitate sequential adsorption and hydrogenation of FFR. Under elevated H2 pressure, the hydrogen dissociation becomes a non-rate limiting step (Figure S5), and the FFR conversion rate is solely related with the concentration of Coδ+ sites. In our work, we noted a strong relevance between the ratio of Coδ+ species over total Co species (Coδ+/Cototal) and FFR conversion rate (Figure S13). Wei et al. similarly showed that interfacial Coδ+ species act as the intrinsic active site for CO bond adsorption, and a linear relationship between the FFR reaction rate and concentration of Coδ+ was found [52]. Therefore, the abundant dual acidic sites and rich Coδ+ species tuned by reduction temperature make Co/Nb2O5-H(550) to be the optimized catalyst for the one-pot xylose conversion process. 3 Conclusion In this study, a one-pot conversion strategy to produce high-value CPO from xylose was developed. By investigating the distribution behavior of key intermediates and products, the impact of different biphasic solvent on xylose conversion and product selectivity was revealed. Toluene/water system is ideal for such one-pot conversion due to its higher FFR and CPO extraction capacity, while maintaining a balanced distribution for other key intermediates in aqueous phases to facilitate FOL ring arrangement. In the second stage process, precious metals (such as Pt, Pd, Ru) showed a retarded catalytic performance due to catalyst poisoning associated with carboxylic acids (such as lactic acid and formic acid) generated in the dehydration of xylose to furfural. In contrast, Co/Nb2O5 showed an outstanding poisoning-resistant capacity and higher CPO selectivity through the one-pot conversion. Structure analysis of Co/Nb2O5 catalysts from varied reduction temperatures showed that electron-deficient Coδ+ species are critical for furfural conversion. In an optimal scenario, Co/Nb2O5-H(550) catalyst exhibited the highest overall CPO yield of 53 % through the one-pot conversion process, attributed to the synergistic effect of rich dual acidic sites and abundant Coδ+ species. Overall, this study presents a highly efficient and economically viable strategy for the one-pot conversion of xylose into CPO, leveraging the uniqueness of biphasic system and non-precious metal catalyst for economic production of biomass-derived high value chemicals. coredata.dc:description: Cyclopentanone (CPO) is a versatile chemical intermediate with great industrial relevance. In this work, a sustainable one-pot process converting xylose to CPO was developed via biphasic solvent engineering and a multifunctional Co/Nb2O5 catalyst, overcoming challenges of intermediate condensation and catalyst poisoning. Biphasic solvent system was formulated to integrate the two-stage process, based on the partitioning behavior of key intermediates to avoid unfavorable condensation while maintaining effective acid-assisted ring arrangement in aqueous phase. Co/Nb2O5 outperformed noble metals with 53 % CPO selectivity, attributed to its dual Brönsted/Lewis acidity, moderate hydrogenation capability, and resistance to carboxylic acid byproducts poisoning. Further structure-activity relationship analysis demonstrated that reduction temperature dependent Coδ+ species are critical for FFR conversion, with Coδ+/Cototal ratio presented a linear correlation with FFR conversion rate. This integrated strategy eliminates energy-intensive steps, offering a practical guidance toward catalytic reaction system design for facile and efficient one-pot conversion of xylose to industrially high-value compounds.
